summary.long: 1 Kings is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: King David was very old; even when they covered him with blankets, he could not get warm.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His servants advised him, “A young virgin must be found for our master, the king, to take care of the king’s needs and serve as his nurse. She can also sleep with you and keep our master, the king, warm.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they looked through all Israel for a beautiful young woman and found Abishag, a Shunammite, and brought her to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The young woman was very beautiful; she became the king’s nurse and served him, but the king was not intimate with her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Adonijah, son of David and Haggith, was promoting himself, boasting, “I will be king!” He managed to acquire chariots and horsemen, as well as fifty men to serve as his royal guard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Now his father had never corrected him by saying, “Why do you do such things?” He was also very handsome and had been born right after Absalom.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He collaborated with Joab son of Zeruiah and with Abiathar the priest, and they supported him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Zadok the priest, Benaiah son of Jehoiada, Nathan the prophet, Shimei, Rei, and David’s elite warriors did not ally themselves with Adonijah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adonijah sacrificed sheep, cattle, and fattened steers at the Stone of Zoheleth near En Rogel. He invited all his brothers, the king’s sons, as well as all the men of Judah, the king’s servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he did not invite Nathan the prophet, Benaiah, the elite warriors, or his brother Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nathan said to Bathsheba, Solomon’s mother, “Has it been reported to you that Haggith’s son Adonijah has become king behind our master David’s back?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now let me give you some advice as to how you can save your life and your son Solomon’s life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Visit King David and say to him, ‘My master, O king, did you not solemnly promise your servant, “Surely your son Solomon will be king after me; he will sit on my throne”? So why has Adonijah become king?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While you are still there speaking to the king, I will arrive and verify your report.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Bathsheba visited the king in his private quarters. (The king was very old, and Abishag the Shunammite was serving the king.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bathsheba bowed down on the floor before the king. The king said, “What do you want?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She replied to him, “My master, you swore an oath to your servant by the Lord your God, ‘Solomon your son will be king after me and he will sit on my throne.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now, look, Adonijah has become king! But you, my master the king, are not even aware of it!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He has sacrificed many cattle, steers, and sheep and has invited all the king’s sons, Abiathar the priest, and Joab, the commander of the army, but he has not invited your servant Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, my master, O king, all Israel is watching anxiously to see who is named to succeed my master the king on the throne.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If a decision is not made, when my master the king is buried with his ancestors, my son Solomon and I will be considered state criminals.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just then, while she was still speaking to the king, Nathan the prophet arrived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king was told, “Nathan the prophet is here.” Nathan entered and bowed before the king with his face to the floor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nathan said, “My master, O king, did you announce, ‘Adonijah will be king after me; he will sit on my throne’?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For today he has gone down and sacrificed many cattle, steers, and sheep and has invited all the king’s sons, the army commanders, and Abiathar the priest. At this moment they are having a feast in his presence, and they have declared, ‘Long live King Adonijah!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he did not invite me—your servant—or Zadok the priest, or Benaiah son of Jehoiada, or your servant Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Has my master the king authorized this without informing your servants who should succeed my master the king on his throne?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King David responded, “Summon Bathsheba!” She came and stood before the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king swore an oath: “As certainly as the Lord lives (he who has rescued me from every danger),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will keep today the oath I swore to you by the Lord God of Israel: ‘Surely Solomon your son will be king after me; he will sit in my place on my throne.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bathsheba bowed down to the king with her face to the floor and said, “May my master, King David, live forever!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King David said, “Summon Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah son of Jehoiada.” They came before the king,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he told them, “Take your master’s servants with you, put my son Solomon on my mule, and lead him down to Gihon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet will anoint him king over Israel; then blow the trumpet and declare, ‘Long live King Solomon!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then follow him up as he comes and sits on my throne. He will be king in my place; I have decreed that he will be ruler over Israel and Judah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Benaiah son of Jehoiada responded to the king: “So be it! May the Lord God of my master the king confirm it!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the Lord is with my master the king, so may he be with Solomon, and may he make him an even greater king than my master King David!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, Benaiah son of Jehoiada, the Kerethites, and the Pelethites went down, put Solomon on King David’s mule, and led him to Gihon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zadok the priest took a horn filled with olive oil from the tent and poured it on Solomon; the trumpet was blown and all the people declared, “Long live King Solomon!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people followed him up, playing flutes and celebrating so loudly they made the ground shake.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Adonijah and all his guests heard the commotion just as they had finished eating. When Joab heard the sound of the trumpet, he asked, “Why is there such a noisy commotion in the city?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As he was still speaking, Jonathan son of Abiathar the priest arrived. Adonijah said, “Come in, for an important man like you must be bringing good news.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan replied to Adonijah: “No! Our master King David has made Solomon king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king sent with him Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, Benaiah son of Jehoiada, the Kerethites, and the Pelethites and they put him on the king’s mule.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet anointed him king in Gihon. They went up from there rejoicing, and the city is in an uproar. That is the sound you hear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, Solomon has assumed the royal throne.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king’s servants have even come to congratulate our master King David, saying, ‘May your God make Solomon more famous than you and make him an even greater king than you!’ Then the king leaned on the bed
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and said this: ‘The Lord God of Israel is worthy of praise because today he has placed a successor on my throne and allowed me to see it.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of Adonijah’s guests panicked; they jumped up and rushed off their separate ways.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adonijah feared Solomon, so he got up and went and grabbed hold of the horns of the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon was told, “Look, Adonijah fears you; see, he has taken hold of the horns of the altar, saying, ‘May King Solomon solemnly promise me today that he will not kill his servant with the sword.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon said, “If he is a loyal subject, not a hair of his head will be harmed, but if he is found to be a traitor, he will die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon sent men to bring him down from the altar. He came and bowed down to King Solomon, and Solomon told him, “Go home.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David was close to death, he told Solomon his son:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I am about to die. Be strong and become a man!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do the job the Lord your God has assigned you by following his instructions and obeying his rules, commandments, regulations, and laws as written in the law of Moses. Then you will succeed in all you do and seek to accomplish,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the Lord will fulfill his promise to me, ‘If your descendants watch their step and live faithfully in my presence with all their heart and being, then,’ he promised, ‘you will not fail to have a successor on the throne of Israel.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You know what Joab son of Zeruiah did to me—how he murdered two commanders of the Israelite armies, Abner son of Ner and Amasa son of Jether. During peacetime he struck them down as if in battle; when he shed their blood, he stained the belt on his waist and the sandals on his feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do to him what you think is appropriate, but don’t let him live long and die a peaceful death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Treat fairly the sons of Barzillai of Gilead and provide for their needs, because they helped me when I had to flee from your brother Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Note well, you still have to contend with Shimei son of Gera, the Benjaminite from Bahurim, who tried to call down upon me a horrible judgment when I went to Mahanaim. He came down and met me at the Jordan, and I solemnly promised him by the Lord, ‘I will not strike you down with the sword.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now don’t treat him as if he were innocent. You are a wise man and you know how to handle him; make sure he has a bloody death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David passed away and was buried in the City of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David reigned over Israel forty years; he reigned in Hebron seven years, and in Jerusalem thirty-three years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon sat on his father David’s throne, and his royal authority was firmly solidified.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Haggith’s son Adonijah visited Bathsheba, Solomon’s mother. She asked, “Do you come in peace?” He answered, “Yes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He added, “I have something to say to you.” She replied, “Speak.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “You know that the kingdom was mine and all Israel considered me king. But then the kingdom was given to my brother, for the Lord decided it should be his.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now I’d like to ask you for just one thing. Please don’t refuse me.” She said, “Go ahead and ask.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “Please ask King Solomon if he would give me Abishag the Shunammite as a wife, for he won’t refuse you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bathsheba replied, “That’s fine; I’ll speak to the king on your behalf.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Bathsheba visited King Solomon to speak to him on Adonijah’s behalf. The king got up to greet her, bowed to her, and then sat on his throne. He ordered a throne to be brought for the king’s mother, and she sat at his right hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She said, “I would like to ask you for just one small favor. Please don’t refuse me.” He said, “Go ahead and ask, my mother, for I would not refuse you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She said, “Allow Abishag the Shunammite to be given to your brother Adonijah as a wife.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon answered his mother, “Why just request Abishag the Shunammite for him? Since he is my older brother, you should also request the kingdom for him, for Abiathar the priest, and for Joab son of Zeruiah!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon then swore an oath by the Lord, “May God judge me severely, if Adonijah does not pay for this request with his life!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, as certainly as the Lord lives (he who made me secure, allowed me to sit on my father David’s throne, and established a dynasty for me as he promised), Adonijah will be executed today!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon then sent Benaiah son of Jehoiada, and he killed Adonijah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king then told Abiathar the priest, “Go back to your property in Anathoth. You deserve to die, but today I will not kill you because you did carry the ark of the Sovereign Lord before my father David and you suffered with my father through all his difficult times.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon removed Abiathar from being a priest for the Lord, fulfilling the Lord’s message that he had pronounced against the family of Eli in Shiloh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the news reached Joab (for Joab had supported Adonijah, although he had not supported Absalom), he ran to the tent of the Lord and grabbed hold of the horns of the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King Solomon heard that Joab had run to the tent of the Lord and was right there beside the altar, he ordered Benaiah son of Jehoiada, “Go, strike him down.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Benaiah arrived at the tent of the Lord, he said to him, “The king says, ‘Come out!’” But he replied, “No, I will die here!” So Benaiah sent word to the king and reported Joab’s reply.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king told him, “Do as he said! Strike him down and bury him. Take away from me and from my father’s family the guilt of Joab’s murderous, bloody deeds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May the Lord punish him for the blood he shed; behind my father David’s back he struck down and murdered with the sword two men who were more innocent and morally upright than he—Abner son of Ner, commander of Israel’s army, and Amasa son of Jether, commander of Judah’s army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May Joab and his descendants be perpetually guilty of their shed blood, but may the Lord give perpetual peace to David, his descendants, his family, and his dynasty.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Benaiah son of Jehoiada went up and executed Joab; he was buried at his home in the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king appointed Benaiah son of Jehoiada to take his place at the head of the army, and the king appointed Zadok the priest to take Abiathar’s place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next the king summoned Shimei and told him, “Build yourself a house in Jerusalem and live there, but you may not leave there to go anywhere.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you ever do leave and cross the Kidron Valley, know for sure that you will certainly die. You will be responsible for your own death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shimei said to the king, “My master the king’s proposal is acceptable. Your servant will do as you say.” So Shimei lived in Jerusalem for a long time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three years later two of Shimei’s servants ran away to King Achish son of Maacah of Gath. Shimei was told, “Look, your servants are in Gath.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Shimei got up, saddled his donkey, and went to Achish at Gath to find his servants; Shimei went and brought back his servants from Gath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Solomon was told that Shimei had gone from Jerusalem to Gath and had then returned,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the king summoned Shimei and said to him, “You will recall that I made you take an oath by the Lord, and I solemnly warned you, ‘If you ever leave and go anywhere, know for sure that you will certainly die.’ You said to me, ‘The proposal is acceptable; I agree to it.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why then have you broken the oath you made before the Lord and disobeyed the order I gave you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to Shimei, “You are well aware of the way you mistreated my father David. The Lord will punish you for what you did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But King Solomon will be empowered, and David’s dynasty will endure permanently before the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king then gave the order to Benaiah son of Jehoiada who went and executed Shimei.
So Solomon took firm control of the kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon made an alliance by marriage with Pharaoh, king of Egypt; he married Pharaoh’s daughter. He brought her to the City of David until he could finish building his residence and the temple of the Lord and the wall around Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the people were offering sacrifices at the high places, because in those days a temple had not yet been built to honor the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon demonstrated his loyalty to the Lord by following the practices of his father David, except that he offered sacrifices and burned incense on the high places.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king went to Gibeon to offer sacrifices, for it had the most prominent of the high places. Solomon would offer up 1,000 burnt sacrifices on the altar there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One night in Gibeon the Lord appeared to Solomon in a dream. God said, “Tell me what I should give you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon replied, “You demonstrated great loyalty to your servant, my father David, as he served you faithfully, properly, and sincerely. You have maintained this great loyalty to this day by allowing his son to sit on his throne.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, O Lord my God, you have made your servant king in my father David’s place, even though I am only a young man and am inexperienced.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your servant stands among your chosen people; they are a great nation that is too numerous to count or number.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So give your servant a discerning mind so he can make judicial decisions for your people and distinguish right from wrong. Otherwise no one is able to make judicial decisions for this great nation of yours.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord was pleased that Solomon made this request.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God said to him, “Because you asked for the ability to make wise judicial decisions, and not for long life, or riches, or vengeance on your enemies,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I grant your request and give you a wise and discerning mind superior to that of anyone who has preceded or will succeed you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, I am giving you what you did not request—riches and honor so that you will be the greatest king of your generation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you follow my instructions by obeying my rules and regulations, just as your father David did, then I will grant you long life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon then woke up and realized it was a dream. He went to Jerusalem, stood before the ark of the Lord’s covenant, offered up burnt sacrifices, presented peace offerings, and held a feast for all his servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then two prostitutes came to the king and stood before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One of the women said, “My master, this woman and I live in the same house. I had a baby while she was with me in the house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then three days after I had my baby, this woman also had a baby. We were alone; there was no one else in the house except the two of us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This woman’s child suffocated during the night when she rolled on top of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She got up in the middle of the night and took my son from my side, while your servant was sleeping. She put him in her arms, and put her dead son in my arms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I got up in the morning to nurse my son, and there he was, dead! But when I examined him carefully in the morning, I realized it was not my baby.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The other woman said, “No! My son is alive; your son is dead!” But the first woman replied, “No, your son is dead; my son is alive.” Each presented her case before the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said, “One says, ‘My son is alive; your son is dead,’ while the other says, ‘No, your son is dead; my son is alive.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king ordered, “Get me a sword.” So they placed a sword before the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king then said, “Cut the living child in two, and give half to one and half to the other!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The real mother spoke up to the king, for her motherly instincts were awakened. She said, “My master, give her the living child! Whatever you do, don’t kill him!” But the other woman said, “Neither one of us will have him. Let them cut him in two!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king responded, “Give the first woman the living child; don’t kill him. She is the mother.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all Israel heard about the judicial decision which the king had rendered, they respected the king, for they realized that he possessed divine wisdom to make judicial decisions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon ruled over all Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were his officials:
Azariah son of Zadok was the priest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Elihoreph and Ahijah, the sons of Shisha, wrote down what happened.
Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was in charge of the records.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Benaiah son of Jehoiada was commander of the army.
Zadok and Abiathar were priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Azariah son of Nathan was supervisor of the district governors.
Zabud son of Nathan was a priest and adviser to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ahishar was supervisor of the palace.
Adoniram son of Abda was supervisor of the work crews.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon had twelve district governors appointed throughout Israel who acquired supplies for the king and his palace. Each was responsible for one month in the year.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were their names:
Ben Hur was in charge of the hill country of Ephraim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ben Deker was in charge of Makaz, Shaalbim, Beth Shemesh, and Elon Beth Hanan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ben Hesed was in charge of Arubboth; he controlled Socoh and all the territory of Hepher.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ben Abinadab was in charge of Naphath Dor. (He was married to Solomon’s daughter Taphath.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baana son of Ahilud was in charge of Taanach and Megiddo, as well as all of Beth Shean next to Zarethan below Jezreel, from Beth Shean to Abel Meholah and on past Jokmeam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ben Geber was in charge of Ramoth Gilead; he controlled the villages of Jair son of Manasseh in Gilead, as well as the region of Argob in Bashan, including sixty large walled cities with bronze bars locking their gates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahinadab son of Iddo was in charge of Mahanaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahimaaz was in charge of Naphtali. (He married Solomon’s daughter Basemath.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baana son of Hushai was in charge of Asher and Aloth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat son of Paruah was in charge of Issachar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shimei son of Ela was in charge of Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Geber son of Uri was in charge of the land of Gilead (the territory which had once belonged to King Sihon of the Amorites and to King Og of Bashan). He was sole governor of the area.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Judah and Israel were as innumerable as the sand on the seashore; they had plenty to eat and drink and were happy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (5:1) Solomon ruled all the kingdoms from the Euphrates River to the land of the Philistines, as far as the border of Egypt. These kingdoms paid tribute as Solomon’s subjects throughout his lifetime.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each day Solomon’s royal court consumed thirty cors of finely milled flour, sixty cors of cereal,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ten calves fattened in the stall, 20 calves from the pasture, and 100 sheep, not to mention rams, gazelles, deer, and well-fed birds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His royal court was so large because he ruled over all the kingdoms west of the Euphrates River from Tiphsah to Gaza; he was at peace with all his neighbors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people of Judah and Israel had security; everyone from Dan to Beer Sheba enjoyed the produce of their vines and fig trees throughout Solomon’s lifetime.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon had 4,000 stalls for his chariot horses and 12,000 horses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The district governors acquired supplies for King Solomon and all who ate in his royal palace. Each was responsible for one month in the year; they made sure nothing was lacking.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each one also brought to the assigned location his quota of barley and straw for the various horses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God gave Solomon wisdom and very great discernment; the breadth of his understanding was as infinite as the sand on the seashore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon was wiser than all the men of the east and all the sages of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was wiser than any man, including Ethan the Ezrahite or Heman, Calcol, and Darda, the sons of Mahol. He was famous in all the neighboring nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He composed 3,000 proverbs and 1,005 songs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He produced manuals on botany, describing every kind of plant, from the cedars of Lebanon to the hyssop that grows on walls. He also produced manuals on biology, describing animals, birds, insects, and fish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: People from all nations came to hear Solomon’s display of wisdom; they came from all the kings of the earth who heard about his wisdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (5:15) King Hiram of Tyre sent messengers to Solomon when he heard that he had been anointed king in his father’s place. (Hiram had always been an ally of David.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon then sent this message to Hiram:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You know that my father David was unable to build a temple to honor the Lord his God, for he was busy fighting battles on all fronts while the Lord subdued his enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now the Lord my God has made me secure on all fronts; there is no adversary or dangerous threat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I have decided to build a temple to honor the Lord my God, as the Lord instructed my father David, ‘Your son, whom I will put on your throne in your place, is the one who will build a temple to honor me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now order some cedars of Lebanon to be cut for me. My servants will work with your servants. I will pay your servants whatever you say is appropriate, for you know that we have no one among us who knows how to cut down trees like the Sidonians.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Hiram heard Solomon’s message, he was very happy. He said, “The Lord is worthy of praise today because he has given David a wise son to rule over this great nation.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram then sent this message to Solomon: “I received the message you sent to me. I will give you all the cedars and evergreens you need.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My servants will bring the timber down from Lebanon to the sea. I will send it by sea in raft-like bundles to the place you designate. There I will separate the logs and you can carry them away. In exchange you will supply the food I need for my royal court.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Hiram supplied the cedars and evergreens Solomon needed,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and Solomon supplied Hiram annually with 20,000 cors of wheat as provision for his royal court, as well as 120,000 gallons of pure olive oil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord gave Solomon wisdom, as he had promised him. And Hiram and Solomon were at peace and made a treaty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon conscripted work crews from throughout Israel, 30,000 men in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sent them to Lebanon in shifts of 10,000 men per month. They worked in Lebanon for one month, and then spent two months at home. Adoniram was supervisor of the work crews.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon also had 70,000 common laborers and 80,000 stonecutters in the hills,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: besides 3,300 officials who supervised the workers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: By royal order they supplied large valuable stones in order to build the temple’s foundation with chiseled stone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon’s and Hiram’s construction workers, along with men from Byblos, did the chiseling and prepared the wood and stones for the building of the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the four hundred and eightieth year after the Israelites left Egypt, in the fourth year of Solomon’s reign over Israel, during the month Ziv (the second month), he began building the Lord’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The temple King Solomon built for the Lord was 90 feet long, 30 feet wide, and 45 feet high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The porch in front of the main hall of the temple was 30 feet long, corresponding to the width of the temple. It was 15 feet wide, extending out from the front of the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made framed windows for the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built an extension all around the walls of the temple’s main hall and Holy Place and constructed side rooms in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The bottom floor of the extension was 7½ feet wide, the middle floor 9 feet wide, and the third floor 10½ feet wide. He made ledges on the temple’s outer walls so the beams would not have to be inserted into the walls.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the temple was being built, only stones shaped at the quarry were used; the sound of hammers, pickaxes, or any other iron tool was not heard at the temple while it was being built.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entrance to the bottom level of side rooms was on the south side of the temple; stairs went up to the middle floor and then on up to the third floor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He finished building the temple and covered it with rafters and boards made of cedar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built an extension all around the temple; it was 7½ feet high and it was attached to the temple by cedar beams.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord’s message came to Solomon:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “As for this temple you are building, if you follow my rules, observe my regulations, and obey all my commandments, I will fulfill through you the promise I made to your father David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will live among the Israelites and will not abandon my people Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Solomon finished building the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He constructed the walls inside the temple with cedar planks; he paneled the inside with wood from the floor of the temple to the rafters of the ceiling. He covered the temple floor with boards made from the wood of evergreens.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built a wall 30 feet in from the rear of the temple as a partition for an inner sanctuary that would be the Most Holy Place. He paneled the wall with cedar planks from the floor to the rafters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The main hall in front of the inner sanctuary was 60 feet long.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The inside of the temple was all cedar and was adorned with carvings of round ornaments and of flowers in bloom. Everything was cedar; no stones were visible.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He prepared the inner sanctuary inside the temple so that the ark of the covenant of the Lord could be placed there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The inner sanctuary was 30 feet long, 30 feet wide, and 30 feet high. He plated it with gold, as well as the cedar altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon plated the inside of the temple with gold. He hung golden chains in front of the inner sanctuary and plated the inner sanctuary with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He plated the entire inside of the temple with gold, as well as the altar inside the inner sanctuary.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the inner sanctuary he made two cherubim of olive wood; each stood 15 feet high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each of the first cherub’s wings was 7½ feet long; its entire wingspan was 15 feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The second cherub also had a wingspan of 15 feet; it was identical to the first in measurements and shape.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each cherub stood 15 feet high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He put the cherubim in the inner sanctuary of the temple. Their wings were spread out. One of the first cherub’s wings touched one wall and one of the other cherub’s wings touched the opposite wall. The first cherub’s other wing touched the second cherub’s other wing in the middle of the room.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He plated the cherubim with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On all the walls around the temple, inside and out, he carved cherubim, palm trees, and flowers in bloom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He plated the floor of the temple with gold, inside and out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made doors of olive wood at the entrance to the inner sanctuary; the pillar on each doorpost was five-sided.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the two doors made of olive wood he carved cherubim, palm trees, and flowers in bloom, and he plated them with gold. He plated the cherubim and the palm trees with hammered gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the same way he made doorposts of olive wood for the entrance to the main hall, only with four-sided pillars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also made two doors out of wood from evergreens; each door had two folding leaves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He carved cherubim, palm trees, and flowers in bloom and plated them with gold, leveled out over the carvings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built the inner courtyard with three rows of chiseled stones and a row of cedar beams.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the month of Ziv in the fourth year of Solomon’s reign the foundation was laid for the Lord’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the eleventh year, in the month of Bul (the eighth month) the temple was completed in accordance with all its specifications and blueprints. It took seven years to build.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon took thirteen years to build his palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He named it “The Palace of the Lebanon Forest”; it was 150 feet long, 75 feet wide, and 45 feet high. It had four rows of cedar pillars and cedar beams above the pillars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The roof above the beams supported by the pillars was also made of cedar; there were forty-five beams, fifteen per row.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were three rows of windows arranged in sets of three.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the entrances were rectangular in shape and they were arranged in sets of three.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made a colonnade 75 feet long and 45 feet wide. There was a porch in front of this and pillars and a roof in front of the porch.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also made a throne room, called “The Hall of Judgment,” where he made judicial decisions. It was paneled with cedar from the floor to the rafters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The palace where he lived was constructed in a similar way. He also constructed a palace like this hall for Pharaoh’s daughter, whom he had married.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All these were built with the best stones, chiseled to the right size and cut with a saw on all sides, from the foundation to the edge of the roof and from the outside to the great courtyard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The foundation was made of large valuable stones, measuring either 15 feet or 12 feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Above the foundation the best stones, chiseled to the right size, were used along with cedar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Around the great courtyard were three rows of chiseled stones and one row of cedar beams, like the inner courtyard of the Lord’s temple and the hall of the palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon sent for Hiram of Tyre.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was the son of a widow from the tribe of Naphtali, and his father was a craftsman in bronze from Tyre. He had the skill and knowledge to make all kinds of works of bronze. He reported to King Solomon and did all the work he was assigned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He fashioned two bronze pillars; each pillar was 27 feet high and 18 feet in circumference.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made two bronze tops for the pillars; each was 7½ feet high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The latticework on the tops of the pillars was adorned with ornamental wreaths and chains; the top of each pillar had seven groupings of ornaments.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he made the pillars, there were two rows of pomegranate-shaped ornaments around the latticework covering the top of each pillar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The tops of the two pillars in the porch were shaped like lilies and were six feet high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the top of each pillar, right above the bulge beside the latticework, there were 200 pomegranate-shaped ornaments arranged in rows all the way around.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He set up the pillars on the porch in front of the main hall. He erected one pillar on the right side and called it Yakin; he erected the other pillar on the left side and called it Boaz.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The tops of the pillars were shaped like lilies. So the construction of the pillars was completed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also made the large bronze basin called “The Sea.” It measured 15 feet from rim to rim, was circular in shape, and stood 7½ feet high. Its circumference was 45 feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Under the rim all the way around it were round ornaments arranged in settings 15 feet long. The ornaments were in two rows and had been cast with “The Sea.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The Sea” stood on top of twelve bulls. Three faced northward, three westward, three southward, and three eastward. “The Sea” was placed on top of them, and they all faced outward.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was four fingers thick and its rim was like that of a cup shaped like a lily blossom. It could hold about 12,000 gallons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also made ten bronze movable stands. Each stand was 6 feet long, 6 feet wide, and 4½ feet high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The stands were constructed with frames between the joints.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On these frames and joints were ornamental lions, bulls, and cherubim. Under the lions and bulls were decorative wreaths.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each stand had four bronze wheels with bronze axles and four supports. Under the basin the supports were fashioned on each side with wreaths.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Inside the stand was a round opening that was 18 inches deep; it had a support that was 27 inches long. On the edge of the opening were carvings in square frames.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The four wheels were under the frames, and the crossbars of the axles were connected to the stand. Each wheel was 27 inches high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The wheels were constructed like chariot wheels; their crossbars, rims, spokes, and hubs were made of cast metal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each stand had four supports, one per side projecting out from the stand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On top of each stand was a round opening three-quarters of a foot deep; there were also supports and frames on top of the stands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He engraved ornamental cherubim, lions, and palm trees on the plates of the supports and frames wherever there was room, with wreaths all around.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made the ten stands in this way. All of them were cast in one mold and were identical in measurements and shape.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also made ten bronze basins, each of which could hold about 240 gallons. Each basin was 6 feet in diameter; there was one basin for each stand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He put five basins on the south side of the temple and five on the north side. He put “The Sea” on the south side, in the southeast corner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram also made basins, shovels, and bowls. He finished all the work on the Lord’s temple he had been assigned by King Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made the two pillars, the two bowl-shaped tops of the pillars, the latticework for the bowl-shaped tops of the two pillars,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the 400 pomegranate-shaped ornaments for the latticework of the two pillars (each latticework had two rows of these ornaments at the bowl-shaped top of the pillar),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the ten movable stands with their ten basins,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the big bronze basin called “The Sea” with its twelve bulls underneath,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the pots, shovels, and bowls. All these items King Solomon assigned Hiram to make for the Lord’s temple were made from polished bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king had them cast in earth foundries in the region of the Jordan between Sukkoth and Zarethan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon left all these items unweighed; there were so many of them they did not weigh the bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon also made all these items for the Lord’s temple: the gold altar, the gold table on which was kept the Bread of the Presence,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the pure gold lampstands at the entrance to the inner sanctuary (five on the right and five on the left), the gold flower-shaped ornaments, lamps, and tongs,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the pure gold bowls, trimming shears, basins, pans, and censers, and the gold door sockets for the inner sanctuary (the Most Holy Place) and for the doors of the main hall of the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King Solomon finished constructing the Lord’s temple, he put the holy items that belonged to his father David (the silver, gold, and other articles) in the treasuries of the Lord’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon convened in Jerusalem Israel’s elders, all the leaders of the Israelite tribes and families, so they could witness the transferal of the ark of the Lord’s covenant from the City of David (that is, Zion).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the men of Israel assembled before King Solomon during the festival in the month of Ethanim (the seventh month).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all Israel’s elders had arrived, the priests lifted the ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests and Levites carried the ark of the Lord, the tent of meeting, and all the holy items in the tent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now King Solomon and all the Israelites who had assembled with him went on ahead of the ark and sacrificed more sheep and cattle than could be counted or numbered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests brought the ark of the Lord’s covenant to its assigned place in the inner sanctuary of the temple, in the Most Holy Place, under the wings of the cherubim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The cherubim’s wings extended over the place where the ark sat; the cherubim overshadowed the ark and its poles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The poles were so long their ends were visible from the Holy Place in front of the inner sanctuary, but they could not be seen from beyond that point. They have remained there to this very day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was nothing in the ark except the two stone tablets Moses had placed there in Horeb. It was there that the Lord made a covenant with the Israelites after he brought them out of the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once the priests left the Holy Place, a cloud filled the Lord’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests could not carry out their duties because of the cloud; the Lord’s glory filled his temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon said, “The Lord has said that he lives in thick darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: O Lord, truly I have built a lofty temple for you, a place where you can live permanently.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king turned around and pronounced a blessing over the whole Israelite assembly as they stood there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “The Lord God of Israel is worthy of praise because he has fulfilled what he promised my father David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He told David, ‘Since the day I brought my people Israel out of Egypt, I have not chosen a city from all the tribes of Israel to build a temple in which to live. But I have chosen David to lead my people Israel.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now my father David had a strong desire to build a temple to honor the Lord God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord told my father David, ‘It is right for you to have a strong desire to build a temple to honor me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you will not build the temple; your very own son will build the temple for my honor.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord has kept the promise he made. I have taken my father David’s place and have occupied the throne of Israel, as the Lord promised. I have built this temple for the honor of the Lord God of Israel
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and set up in it a place for the ark containing the covenant the Lord made with our ancestors when he brought them out of the land of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon stood before the altar of the Lord in front of the entire assembly of Israel and spread out his hands toward the sky.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He prayed: “O Lord, God of Israel, there is no god like you in heaven above or on earth below! You maintain covenantal loyalty to your servants who obey you with sincerity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You have kept your word to your servant, my father David; this very day you have fulfilled what you promised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, O Lord, God of Israel, keep the promise you made to your servant, my father David, when you said, ‘You will never fail to have a successor ruling before me on the throne of Israel, provided that your descendants watch their step and serve me as you have done.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, O God of Israel, may the promise you made to your servant, my father David, be realized.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “God does not really live on the earth! Look, if the sky and the highest heaven cannot contain you, how much less this temple I have built!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But respond favorably to your servant’s prayer and his request for help, O Lord my God. Answer the desperate prayer your servant is presenting to you today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Night and day may you watch over this temple, the place where you promised you would live. May you answer your servant’s prayer for this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Respond to the request of your servant and your people Israel for this place. Hear from inside your heavenly dwelling place and respond favorably.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When someone is accused of sinning against his neighbor and the latter pronounces a curse on the alleged offender before your altar in this temple, be willing to forgive the accused if the accusation is false.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Listen from heaven and make a just decision about your servants’ claims. Condemn the guilty party, declare the other innocent, and give both of them what they deserve.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The time will come when your people Israel are defeated by an enemy because they sinned against you. If they come back to you, renew their allegiance to you, and pray for your help in this temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then listen from heaven, forgive the sin of your people Israel, and bring them back to the land you gave to their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The time will come when the skies are shut up tightly and no rain falls because your people sinned against you. When they direct their prayers toward this place, renew their allegiance to you, and turn away from their sin because you punish them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then listen from heaven and forgive the sin of your servants, your people Israel. Certainly you will then teach them the right way to live and send rain on your land that you have given your people to possess.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The time will come when the land suffers from a famine, a plague, blight and disease, or a locust invasion, or when their enemy lays siege to the cities of the land, or when some other type of plague or epidemic occurs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all your people Israel pray and ask for help, as they acknowledge their pain and spread out their hands toward this temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then listen from your heavenly dwelling place, forgive their sin, and act favorably toward each one based on your evaluation of his motives. (Indeed you are the only one who can correctly evaluate the motives of all people.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they will obey you throughout their lifetimes as they live on the land you gave to our ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Foreigners, who do not belong to your people Israel, will come from a distant land because of your reputation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they hear about your great reputation and your ability to accomplish mighty deeds, they will come and direct their prayers toward this temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then listen from your heavenly dwelling place and answer all the prayers of the foreigners. Then all the nations of the earth will acknowledge your reputation, obey you as your people Israel do, and recognize that this temple I built belongs to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When you direct your people to march out and fight their enemies, and they direct their prayers to the Lord toward his chosen city and this temple I built for your honor,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then listen from heaven to their prayers for help and vindicate them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The time will come when your people will sin against you (for there is no one who is sinless!) and you will be angry with them and deliver them over to their enemies, who will take them as prisoners to their own land, whether far away or close by.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When your people come to their senses in the land where they are held prisoner, they will repent and beg for your mercy in the land of their imprisonment, admitting, ‘We have sinned and gone astray; we have done evil.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they return to you with all their heart and being in the land where they are held prisoner, and direct their prayers to you toward the land you gave to their ancestors, your chosen city, and the temple I built for your honor,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then listen from your heavenly dwelling place to their prayers for help and vindicate them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Forgive all the rebellious acts of your sinful people and cause their captors to have mercy on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After all, they are your people and your special possession whom you brought out of Egypt, from the middle of the iron-smelting furnace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “May you be attentive to your servant’s and your people Israel’s requests for help and may you respond to all their prayers to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After all, you picked them out of all the nations of the earth to be your special possession, just as you, O Sovereign Lord, announced through your servant Moses when you brought our ancestors out of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Solomon finished presenting all these prayers and requests to the Lord, he got up from before the altar of the Lord where he had kneeled and spread out his hands toward the sky.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he stood up, he pronounced a blessing over the entire assembly of Israel, saying in a loud voice:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The Lord is worthy of praise because he has made Israel his people secure just as he promised! Not one of all the faithful promises he made through his servant Moses is left unfulfilled!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May the Lord our God be with us, as he was with our ancestors. May he not abandon us or leave us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May he make us submissive, so we can follow all his instructions and obey the commandments, rules, and regulations he commanded our ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May the Lord our God be constantly aware of these requests of mine I have presented to him, so that he might vindicate his servant and his people Israel as the need arises.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the nations of the earth will recognize that the Lord is the only genuine God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May you demonstrate wholehearted devotion to the Lord our God by following his rules and obeying his commandments, as you are now doing.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king and all Israel with him were presenting sacrifices to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon offered as peace offerings to the Lord 22,000 cattle and 120,000 sheep. Then the king and all the Israelites dedicated the Lord’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day the king consecrated the middle of the courtyard that is in front of the Lord’s temple. He offered there burnt sacrifices, grain offerings, and the fat from the peace offerings, because the bronze altar that stood before the Lord was too small to hold all these offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time Solomon and all Israel with him celebrated a festival before the Lord our God for two entire weeks. This great assembly included people from all over the land, from Lebo Hamath in the north to the Stream of Egypt in the south.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the fifteenth day after the festival started, he dismissed the people. They asked God to empower the king and then went to their homes, happy and content because of all the good the Lord had done for his servant David and his people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Solomon finished building the Lord’s temple, the royal palace, and all the other construction projects he had planned,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the Lord appeared to Solomon a second time, in the same way he had appeared to him at Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to him, “I have answered your prayer and your request for help that you made to me. I have consecrated this temple you built by making it my permanent home; I will be constantly present there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must serve me with integrity and sincerity, just as your father David did. Do everything I commanded and obey my rules and regulations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I will allow your dynasty to rule over Israel permanently, just as I promised your father David, ‘You will not fail to have a successor on the throne of Israel.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “But if you or your sons ever turn away from me, fail to obey the regulations and rules I instructed you to keep, and decide to serve and worship other gods,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then I will remove Israel from the land I have given them, I will abandon this temple I have consecrated with my presence, and Israel will be mocked and ridiculed among all the nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This temple will become a heap of ruins; everyone who passes by it will be shocked and will hiss out their scorn, saying, ‘Why did the Lord do this to this land and this temple?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Others will then answer, ‘Because they abandoned the Lord their God, who led their ancestors out of Egypt. They embraced other gods whom they worshiped and served. That is why the Lord has brought all this disaster down on them.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After twenty years, during which Solomon built the Lord’s temple and the royal palace,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon gave King Hiram of Tyre twenty towns in the region of Galilee, because Hiram had supplied Solomon with cedars, evergreens, and all the gold he wanted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Hiram went out from Tyre to inspect the towns Solomon had given him, he was not pleased with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram asked, “Why did you give me these towns, my friend?” He called that area the region of Cabul, a name which it has retained to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram had sent to the king 120 talents of gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Here are the details concerning the work crews King Solomon conscripted to build the Lord’s temple, his palace, the terrace, the wall of Jerusalem, and the cities of Hazor, Megiddo, and Gezer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Pharaoh, king of Egypt, had attacked and captured Gezer. He burned it and killed the Canaanites who lived in the city. He gave it as a wedding present to his daughter, who had married Solomon.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon built up Gezer, lower Beth Horon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baalath, Tadmor in the wilderness,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: all the storage cities that belonged to him, and the cities where chariots and horses were kept. He built whatever he wanted in Jerusalem, Lebanon, and throughout his entire kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now several non-Israelite peoples were left in the land after the conquest of Joshua, including the Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their descendants remained in the land (the Israelites were unable to wipe them out completely). Solomon conscripted them for his work crews, and they continue in that role to this very day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon did not assign Israelites to these work crews; the Israelites served as his soldiers, attendants, officers, charioteers, and commanders of his chariot forces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These men were also in charge of Solomon’s work projects; there were a total of 550 men who supervised the workers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon built the terrace as soon as Pharaoh’s daughter moved up from the City of David to the palace Solomon built for her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three times a year Solomon offered burnt offerings and peace offerings on the altar he had built for the Lord, burning incense along with them before the Lord. He made the temple his official worship place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon also built ships in Ezion Geber, which is located near Elat in the land of Edom, on the shore of the Red Sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram sent his fleet and some of his sailors, who were well acquainted with the sea, to serve with Solomon’s men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They sailed to Ophir, took from there 420 talents of gold, and then brought them to King Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the queen of Sheba heard about Solomon, she came to challenge him with difficult questions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She arrived in Jerusalem with a great display of pomp, bringing with her camels carrying spices, a very large quantity of gold, and precious gems. She visited Solomon and discussed with him everything that was on her mind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon answered all her questions; there was no question too complex for the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the queen of Sheba saw for herself Solomon’s extensive wisdom, the palace he had built,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the food in his banquet hall, his servants and attendants, their robes, his cupbearers, and his burnt offerings which he presented in the Lord’s temple, she was amazed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She said to the king, “The report I heard in my own country about your wise sayings and insight was true!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I did not believe these things until I came and saw them with my own eyes. Indeed, I didn’t hear even half the story! Your wisdom and wealth surpass what was reported to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your attendants, who stand before you at all times and hear your wise sayings, are truly happy!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May the Lord your God be praised because he favored you by placing you on the throne of Israel! Because of the Lord’s eternal love for Israel, he made you king so you could make just and right decisions.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She gave the king 120 talents of gold, a very large quantity of spices, and precious gems. The quantity of spices the queen of Sheba gave King Solomon has never been matched.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Hiram’s fleet, which carried gold from Ophir, also brought from Ophir a very large quantity of fine timber and precious gems.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With the timber the king made supports for the Lord’s temple and for the royal palace and stringed instruments for the musicians. No one has seen so much of this fine timber to this very day.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon gave the queen of Sheba everything she requested, besides what he had freely offered her. Then she left and returned to her homeland with her attendants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon received 666 talents of gold per year,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: besides what he collected from the merchants, traders, Arabian kings, and governors of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon made 200 large shields of hammered gold; 600 measures of gold were used for each shield.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also made 300 small shields of hammered gold; three minas of gold were used for each of these shields. The king placed them in the Palace of the Lebanon Forest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king made a large throne decorated with ivory and overlaid it with pure gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were six steps leading up to the throne, and the back of it was rounded on top. The throne had two armrests with a statue of a lion standing on each side.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were twelve statues of lions on the six steps, one lion at each end of each step. There was nothing like it in any other kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of King Solomon’s cups were made of gold, and all the household items in the Palace of the Lebanon Forest were made of pure gold. There were no silver items, for silver was not considered very valuable in Solomon’s time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Along with Hiram’s fleet, the king had a fleet of large merchant ships that sailed the sea. Once every three years the fleet came into port with cargoes of gold, silver, ivory, apes, and peacocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon was wealthier and wiser than any of the kings of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everyone in the world wanted to visit Solomon to see him display his God-given wisdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Year after year visitors brought their gifts, which included items of silver, items of gold, clothes, perfume, spices, horses, and mules.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon accumulated chariots and horses. He had 1,400 chariots and 12,000 horses. He kept them in assigned cities and in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king made silver as plentiful in Jerusalem as stones; cedar was as plentiful as sycamore fig trees are in the foothills.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon acquired his horses from Egypt and from Que; the king’s traders purchased them from Que.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They paid 600 silver pieces for each chariot from Egypt and 150 silver pieces for each horse. They also sold chariots and horses to all the kings of the Hittites and to the kings of Syria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon fell in love with many foreign women (besides Pharaoh’s daughter), including Moabites, Ammonites, Edomites, Sidonians, and Hittites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They came from nations about which the Lord had warned the Israelites, “You must not establish friendly relations with them! If you do, they will surely shift your allegiance to their gods.” But Solomon was irresistibly attracted to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had 700 royal wives and 300 concubines; his wives had a powerful influence over him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Solomon became old, his wives shifted his allegiance to other gods; he was not wholeheartedly devoted to the Lord his God, as his father David had been.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon worshiped the Sidonian goddess Astarte and the detestable Ammonite god Milcom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon did evil in the Lord’s sight; he did not remain loyal to the Lord, as his father David had.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, on the hill east of Jerusalem Solomon built a high place for the detestable Moabite god Chemosh and for the detestable Ammonite god Milcom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built high places for all his foreign wives so they could burn incense and make sacrifices to their gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord was angry with Solomon because he had shifted his allegiance away from the Lord, the God of Israel, who had appeared to him on two occasions
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and had warned him about this very thing, so that he would not follow other gods. But he did not obey the Lord’s command.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord said to Solomon, “Because you insist on doing these things and have not kept the covenantal rules I gave you, I will surely tear the kingdom away from you and give it to your servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, for your father David’s sake I will not do this while you are alive. I will tear it away from your son’s hand instead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I will not tear away the entire kingdom; I will leave your son one tribe for my servant David’s sake and for the sake of my chosen city Jerusalem.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord brought against Solomon an enemy, Hadad the Edomite, a descendant of the Edomite king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During David’s campaign against Edom, Joab, the commander of the army, while on a mission to bury the dead, killed every male in Edom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For Joab and the entire Israelite army stayed there six months until they had exterminated every male in Edom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hadad, who was only a small boy at the time, escaped with some of his father’s Edomite servants and headed for Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They went from Midian to Paran; they took some men from Paran and went to Egypt. Pharaoh, king of Egypt, gave him a house and some land and supplied him with food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh liked Hadad so well he gave him his sister-in-law (Queen Tahpenes’ sister) as a wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tahpenes’ sister gave birth to his son, named Genubath. Tahpenes raised him in Pharaoh’s palace; Genubath grew up in Pharaoh’s palace among Pharaoh’s sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While in Egypt Hadad heard that David had passed away and that Joab, the commander of the army, was dead. So Hadad asked Pharaoh, “Give me permission to leave so I can return to my homeland.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said to him, “What do you lack here that makes you want to go to your homeland?” Hadad replied, “Nothing, but please give me permission to leave.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God also brought against Solomon another enemy, Rezon son of Eliada who had run away from his master, King Hadadezer of Zobah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He gathered some men and organized a raiding band. When David tried to kill them, they went to Damascus, where they settled down and gained control of the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was Israel’s enemy throughout Solomon’s reign and, like Hadad, caused trouble. He loathed Israel and ruled over Syria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam son of Nebat, one of Solomon’s servants, rebelled against the king. He was an Ephraimite from Zeredah whose mother was a widow named Zeruah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what prompted him to rebel against the king: Solomon built a terrace, and he closed up a gap in the wall of the city of his father David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam was a talented man; when Solomon saw that the young man was an accomplished worker, he made him the leader of the work crew from the tribe of Joseph.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time, when Jeroboam had left Jerusalem, the prophet Ahijah the Shilonite met him on the road; the two of them were alone in the open country. Ahijah was wearing a brand new robe,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and he grabbed the robe and tore it into twelve pieces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he told Jeroboam, “Take ten pieces, for this is what the Lord God of Israel has said: ‘Look, I am about to tear the kingdom from Solomon’s hand and I will give ten tribes to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will retain one tribe, for my servant David’s sake and for the sake of Jerusalem, the city I have chosen out of all the tribes of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am taking the kingdom from him because they have abandoned me and worshiped the Sidonian goddess Astarte, the Moabite god Chemosh, and the Ammonite god Milcom. They have not followed my instructions by doing what I approve and obeying my rules and regulations, as Solomon’s father David did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will not take the whole kingdom from his hand. I will allow him to be ruler for the rest of his life for the sake of my chosen servant David who kept my commandments and rules.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will take the kingdom from the hand of his son and give ten tribes to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will leave his son one tribe so my servant David’s dynasty may continue to serve me in Jerusalem, the city I have chosen as my home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will select you; you will rule over all you desire to have and you will be king over Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must obey all I command you to do, follow my instructions, do what I approve, and keep my rules and commandments, as my servant David did. Then I will be with you and establish for you a lasting dynasty, as I did for David; I will give you Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will humiliate David’s descendants because of this, but not forever.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon tried to kill Jeroboam, but Jeroboam escaped to Egypt and found refuge with King Shishak of Egypt. He stayed in Egypt until Solomon died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events of Solomon’s reign, including all his accomplishments and his wise decisions, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon ruled over all Israel from Jerusalem for forty years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon passed away and was buried in the city of his father David. His son Rehoboam replaced him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam traveled to Shechem, for all Israel had gathered in Shechem to make Rehoboam king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jeroboam son of Nebat heard the news, he was still in Egypt, where he had fled from King Solomon and had been living ever since.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They sent for him, and Jeroboam and the whole Israelite assembly came and spoke to Rehoboam, saying,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Your father made us work too hard. Now if you lighten the demands he made and don’t make us work as hard, we will serve you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to them, “Go away for three days, then return to me.” So the people went away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Rehoboam consulted with the older advisers who had served his father Solomon when he had been alive. He asked them, “How do you advise me to answer these people?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to him, “Today if you will be a servant to these people and grant their request, speaking kind words to them, they will be your servants from this time forward.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Rehoboam rejected their advice and consulted the young advisers who served him, with whom he had grown up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He asked them, “How do you advise me to respond to these people who said to me, ‘Lessen the demands your father placed on us’?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The young advisers with whom Rehoboam had grown up said to him, “Say this to these people who have said to you, ‘Your father made us work hard, but now lighten our burden.’ Say this to them: ‘I am a lot harsher than my father!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My father imposed heavy demands on you; I will make them even heavier. My father punished you with ordinary whips; I will punish you with whips that really sting your flesh.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam and all the people reported to Rehoboam on the third day, just as the king had ordered when he said, “Return to me on the third day.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king responded to the people harshly. He rejected the advice of the older men
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and followed the advice of the younger ones. He said, “My father imposed heavy demands on you; I will make them even heavier. My father punished you with ordinary whips; I will punish you with whips that really sting your flesh.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king refused to listen to the people, because the Lord was instigating this turn of events so that he might bring to pass the prophetic announcement he had made through Ahijah the Shilonite to Jeroboam son of Nebat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all Israel saw that the king refused to listen to them, the people answered the king, “We have no portion in David, no share in the son of Jesse! Return to your homes, O Israel! Now, look after your own dynasty, O David!” So Israel returned to their homes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Rehoboam continued to rule over the Israelites who lived in the cities of Judah.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Rehoboam sent Adoniram, the supervisor of the work crews, out after them, but all Israel stoned him to death. King Rehoboam managed to jump into his chariot and escape to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Israel has been in rebellion against the Davidic dynasty to this very day.
