verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all Israel heard that Jeroboam had returned, they summoned him to the assembly and made him king over all Israel. No one except the tribe of Judah remained loyal to the Davidic dynasty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Rehoboam arrived in Jerusalem, he summoned 180,000 skilled warriors from all Judah and the tribe of Benjamin to attack Israel and restore the kingdom to Rehoboam son of Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But God told Shemaiah the prophet,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Say this to King Rehoboam son of Solomon of Judah, and to all Judah and Benjamin, as well as the rest of the people,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘This is what the Lord has said: “Do not attack and make war with your brothers, the Israelites. Each of you go home. Indeed this thing has happened because of me.”’” So they obeyed the Lord’s message. They went home in keeping with the Lord’s message.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam built up Shechem in the Ephraimite hill country and lived there. From there he went out and built up Penuel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam then thought to himself: “Now the Davidic dynasty could regain the kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If these people go up to offer sacrifices in the Lord’s temple in Jerusalem, their loyalty could shift to their former master, King Rehoboam of Judah. They might kill me and return to King Rehoboam of Judah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the king had consulted with his advisers, he made two golden calves. Then he said to the people, “It is too much trouble for you to go up to Jerusalem. Look, Israel, here are your gods who brought you up from the land of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He put one in Bethel and the other in Dan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This caused Israel to sin; the people went to Bethel and Dan to worship the calves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built temples on the high places and appointed as priests common people who were not Levites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam inaugurated a festival on the fifteenth day of the eighth month, like the festival celebrated in Judah. On the altar in Bethel he offered sacrifices to the calves he had made. In Bethel he also appointed priests for the high places he had made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the fifteenth day of the eighth month (a date he had arbitrarily chosen) Jeroboam offered sacrifices on the altar he had made in Bethel. He inaugurated a festival for the Israelites and went up to the altar to offer sacrifices.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just then a prophet arrived from Judah with the Lord’s message for Bethel, as Jeroboam was standing near the altar ready to offer a sacrifice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He cried out against the altar with the Lord’s message, “O altar, altar! This is what the Lord has said, ‘Look, a son named Josiah will be born to the Davidic dynasty. He will sacrifice on you the priests of the high places who offer sacrifices on you. Human bones will be burned on you.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day he had also given a sign, saying, “This is the sign that the Lord has declared: The altar will split open and the ashes on it will pour out.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the king heard the prophet’s message that he had cried out against the altar in Bethel, Jeroboam took his hand from the altar and pointed it saying, “Seize him!” Then the hand that he had pointed at him stiffened up, and he could not pull it back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile the altar split open, and the ashes poured from the altar in fulfillment of the sign the prophet had given with the Lord’s message.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king responded to the prophet, “Seek the favor of the Lord your God and pray for me, so that my hand may be restored.” So the prophet sought the Lord’s favor and the king’s hand was restored as it was at first.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king then said to the prophet, “Come home with me and have something to eat, so that I may give you a gift.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the prophet said to the king, “Even if you were to give me half your possessions, I would not go with you. I am not allowed to eat food or drink water in this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this is how I was commanded in the Lord’s message, ‘Eat no food. Drink no water. And do not return by the way you came.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he started back on another road; he did not travel back on the same road he had taken to Bethel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now there was an old prophet living in Bethel. When his sons came home, they told him everything the prophet had done in Bethel that day. And they told their father all the words that he had spoken to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their father asked them, “Which road did he take?” His sons showed him the road the prophet from Judah had taken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He then told his sons, “Saddle the donkey for me.” When they had saddled the donkey for him, he mounted it
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and took off after the prophet, whom he found sitting under an oak tree. He asked him, “Are you the prophet from Judah?” He answered, “Yes, I am.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He then said to him, “Come home with me and eat something.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he replied, “I can’t go back with you. I am not allowed to eat food or to drink water with you in this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For an order came to me in the Lord’s message, ‘Eat no food. Drink no water there. And do not return by the way you came.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the old prophet said, “I too am a prophet like you. And an angel has told me in a message from the Lord, ‘Bring him back with you to your house so he can eat food and drink water.’” But he had lied to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the prophet went back with him. He ate food in his house and he drank water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While they were sitting at the table, the Lord’s message came to the old prophet who had brought him back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he cried out to the prophet who had come from Judah, “This is what the Lord has said, ‘You have rebelled against the Lord’s instruction and have not obeyed the command the Lord your God gave you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You went back. You ate food. And you drank water in the place of which he had said to you, “Eat no food. Drink no water.” Therefore your corpse will not be buried in your ancestral tomb.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So this is what happened after he had eaten food and drunk water. The old prophet saddled the donkey for the prophet whom he had brought back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So the prophet from Judah travelled on. Then a lion attacked him on the road and killed him.
There was his body lying on the road, with the donkey standing next to it, and the lion just standing there by the body.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then some men came passing by and saw the body lying in the road with the lion standing next to the body. They went and reported what they had seen in the city where the old prophet lived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the old prophet who had invited him to his house heard the news, he said, “It is the prophet who rebelled against the Lord. The Lord delivered him over to the lion and it tore him up and killed him, in keeping with the Lord’s message that he had spoken to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He told his sons, “Saddle my donkey.” So they saddled it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He went and found the body lying in the road with the donkey and the lion standing beside it; the lion had neither eaten the body nor attacked the donkey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The old prophet picked up the prophet’s body, put it on the donkey, and brought it back. The old prophet then entered the city to mourn him and to bury him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He put the body into his own tomb, and they mourned over him, saying, “Ah, my brother!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After he buried him, he said to his sons, “When I die, bury me in the tomb where the prophet is buried; put my bones right beside his bones,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because the message that he announced as the Lord’s message against the altar in Bethel and against all the temples on the high places in the cities of the north will certainly be fulfilled.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this happened, Jeroboam still did not change his evil ways; he continued to appoint common people as priests at the high places. Anyone who wanted the job he consecrated as a priest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This sin caused Jeroboam’s dynasty to come to an end and to be destroyed from the face of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time Jeroboam’s son Abijah became sick.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam told his wife, “Disguise yourself so that people cannot recognize you are Jeroboam’s wife. Then go to Shiloh; Ahijah the prophet, who told me I would rule over this nation, lives there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take ten loaves of bread, some small cakes, and a container of honey and visit him. He will tell you what will happen to the boy.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam’s wife did as she was told. She went to Shiloh and visited Ahijah. Now Ahijah could not see; he had lost his eyesight in his old age.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord had told Ahijah, “Look, Jeroboam’s wife is coming to find out from you what will happen to her son, for he is sick. Tell her such and such. When she comes, she will be in a disguise.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ahijah heard the sound of her footsteps as she came through the door, he said, “Come on in, wife of Jeroboam! Why are you pretending to be someone else? I have been commissioned to give you bad news.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go, tell Jeroboam, ‘This is what the Lord God of Israel has said: “I raised you up from among the people and made you ruler over my people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I tore the kingdom away from the Davidic dynasty and gave it to you. But you are not like my servant David, who kept my commandments and followed me wholeheartedly by doing only what I approve.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You have sinned more than all who came before you. You went and angered me by making other gods, formed out of metal; you have completely disregarded me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I am ready to bring disaster on the dynasty of Jeroboam. I will cut off every last male belonging to Jeroboam in Israel, including even the weak and incapacitated. I will burn up the dynasty of Jeroboam, just as one burns manure until it is completely consumed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Dogs will eat the members of your family who die in the city, and the birds of the sky will eat the ones who die in the country.”’ Indeed, the Lord has announced it!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “As for you, get up and go home. When you set foot in the city, the boy will die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All Israel will mourn him and bury him. He is the only one in Jeroboam’s family who will receive a decent burial, for he is the only one in whom the Lord God of Israel found anything good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord will raise up a king over Israel who will cut off Jeroboam’s dynasty. It is ready to happen!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord will attack Israel, making it like a reed that sways in the water. He will remove Israel from this good land he gave to their ancestors and scatter them beyond the Euphrates River, because they angered the Lord by making Asherah poles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will hand Israel over to their enemies because of the sins which Jeroboam committed and which he made Israel commit.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeroboam’s wife got up and went back to Tirzah. As she crossed the threshold of the house, the boy died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All Israel buried him and mourned for him, in keeping with the Lord’s message that he had spoken through his servant, the prophet Ahijah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events of Jeroboam’s reign, including the details of his battles and rule, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam ruled for twenty-two years; then he passed away. His son Nadab replaced him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Rehoboam son of Solomon ruled in Judah. He was forty-one years old when he became king and he ruled for seventeen years in Jerusalem, the city the Lord chose from all the tribes of Israel to be his home. His mother was an Ammonite woman named Naamah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah did evil in the sight of the Lord. They made him more jealous by their sins than their ancestors had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They even built for themselves high places, sacred pillars, and Asherah poles on every high hill and under every green tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were also male cultic prostitutes in the land. They committed the same horrible sins as the nations that the Lord had driven out from before the Israelites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In King Rehoboam’s fifth year, King Shishak of Egypt attacked Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took away the treasures of the Lord’s temple and of the royal palace; he took everything, including all the golden shields that Solomon had made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Rehoboam made bronze shields to replace them and assigned them to the officers of the royal guard who protected the entrance to the royal palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever the king visited the Lord’s temple, the royal guard carried them and then brought them back to the guardroom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events of Rehoboam’s reign, including his accomplishments, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam and Jeroboam were continually at war with each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam passed away and was buried with his ancestors in the City of David. His mother was an Ammonite named Naamah. His son Abijah replaced him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the eighteenth year of the reign of Jeroboam son of Nebat, Abijah became king over Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He ruled for three years in Jerusalem. His mother was Maacah, the daughter of Abishalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He followed all the sinful practices of his father before him. He was not wholeheartedly devoted to the Lord his God, as his ancestor David had been.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nevertheless for David’s sake the Lord his God maintained his dynasty in Jerusalem by giving him a son to succeed him and by protecting Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did this because David had done what he approved and had not disregarded any of his commandments his entire lifetime, except for the incident involving Uriah the Hittite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam and Jeroboam were continually at war with each other throughout Abijah’s lifetime.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events of Abijah’s reign, including all his accomplishments, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Judah. Abijah and Jeroboam had been at war with each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abijah passed away and was buried in the City of David. His son Asa replaced him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the twentieth year of Jeroboam’s reign over Israel, Asa became the king of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He ruled for forty-one years in Jerusalem. His grandmother was Maacah daughter of Abishalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa did what the Lord approved as his ancestor David had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He removed the male cultic prostitutes from the land and got rid of all the disgusting idols his ancestors had made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also removed Maacah his grandmother from her position as queen mother because she had made a loathsome Asherah pole. Asa cut down her loathsome pole and burned it in the Kidron Valley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The high places were not eliminated, yet Asa was wholeheartedly devoted to the Lord throughout his lifetime.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought the holy items that he and his father had made into the Lord’s temple, including the silver, gold, and other articles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Asa and King Baasha of Israel were continually at war with each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Baasha of Israel attacked Judah and established Ramah as a military outpost to prevent anyone from leaving or entering the land of King Asa of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa took all the silver and gold that was left in the treasuries of the Lord’s temple and of the royal palace and handed it to his servants. He then told them to deliver it to Ben Hadad son of Tabrimmon, the son of Hezion, king of Syria, ruler in Damascus, along with this message:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I want to make a treaty with you, like the one our fathers made. See, I have sent you silver and gold as a present. Break your treaty with King Baasha of Israel, so he will retreat from my land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ben Hadad accepted King Asa’s offer and ordered his army commanders to attack the cities of Israel. They conquered Ijon, Dan, Abel Beth Maacah, and all the territory of Naphtali, including the region of Kinnereth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Baasha heard the news, he stopped fortifying Ramah and settled down in Tirzah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Asa ordered all the men of Judah (no exemptions were granted) to carry away the stones and wood that Baasha had used to build Ramah. King Asa used the materials to build up Geba (in Benjamin) and Mizpah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events of Asa’s reign, including all his successes and accomplishments, as well as a record of the cities he built, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Judah. Yet when he was very old he developed a foot disease.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa passed away and was buried with his ancestors in the city of his ancestor David. His son Jehoshaphat replaced him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the second year of Asa’s reign over Judah, Jeroboam’s son Nadab became the king of Israel; he ruled Israel for two years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord. He followed in his father’s footsteps and encouraged Israel to sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baasha son of Ahijah, from the tribe of Issachar, conspired against Nadab and assassinated him in Gibbethon, which was in Philistine territory. This happened while Nadab and all the Israelite army were besieging Gibbethon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baasha killed him in the third year of Asa’s reign over Judah and replaced him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he became king, he executed Jeroboam’s entire family. He wiped out everyone who breathed, in keeping with the Lord’s message that he had spoken through his servant Ahijah the Shilonite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This happened because of the sins which Jeroboam committed and which he made Israel commit. These sins angered the Lord God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events of Nadab’s reign, including all his accomplishments, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa and King Baasha of Israel were continually at war with each other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the third year of Asa’s reign over Judah, Baasha son of Ahijah became king over all Israel in Tirzah; he ruled for twenty-four years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord; he followed in Jeroboam’s footsteps and encouraged Israel to sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord’s message against Baasha came to Jehu son of Hanani:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I raised you up from the dust and made you ruler over my people Israel. Yet you followed in Jeroboam’s footsteps and encouraged my people Israel to sin; their sins have made me angry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I am ready to burn up Baasha and his family, and make your family like the family of Jeroboam son of Nebat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Dogs will eat the members of Baasha’s family who die in the city, and the birds of the sky will eat the ones who die in the country.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events of Baasha’s reign, including his accomplishments and successes, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baasha passed away and was buried in Tirzah. His son Elah replaced him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And so it was the Lord’s message came through the prophet Jehu son of Hanani against Baasha and his family. This was because of all the evil he had done in the Lord’s view, by angering him with his deeds and becoming like Jeroboam’s dynasty, and because of how he had destroyed Jeroboam’s dynasty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the twenty-sixth year of Asa’s reign over Judah, Baasha’s son Elah became king over Israel; he ruled in Tirzah for two years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His servant Zimri, a commander of half of his chariot force, conspired against him. While Elah was in Tirzah drinking heavily at the house of Arza, who supervised the palace in Tirzah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zimri came in and struck him dead. (This happened in the twenty-seventh year of Asa’s reign over Judah.) Zimri replaced Elah as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he became king and occupied the throne, he killed Baasha’s entire family. He did not spare any male belonging to him; he killed his relatives and his friends.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zimri destroyed Baasha’s entire family, in keeping with the Lord’s message which he had spoken against Baasha through Jehu the prophet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This happened because of all the sins which Baasha and his son Elah committed and which they made Israel commit. They angered the Lord God of Israel with their worthless idols.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events of Elah’s reign, including all his accomplishments, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the twenty-seventh year of Asa’s reign over Judah, Zimri became king over Israel; he ruled for seven days in Tirzah. Zimri’s revolt took place while the army was deployed in Gibbethon, which was in Philistine territory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While deployed there, the army received this report: “Zimri has conspired against the king and assassinated him.” So all Israel made Omri, the commander of the army, king over Israel that very day in the camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Omri and all Israel went up from Gibbethon and besieged Tirzah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Zimri saw that the city was captured, he went into the fortified area of the royal palace. He set the palace on fire and died in the flames.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This happened because of the sins he committed. He did evil in the sight of the Lord and followed in Jeroboam’s footsteps and encouraged Israel to continue sinning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events of Zimri’s reign, including the details of his revolt, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time the people of Israel were divided in their loyalties. Half the people supported Tibni son of Ginath and wanted to make him king; the other half supported Omri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Omri’s supporters were stronger than those who supported Tibni son of Ginath. Tibni died; Omri became king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the thirty-first year of Asa’s reign over Judah, Omri became king over Israel. He ruled for twelve years, six of them in Tirzah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He purchased the hill of Samaria from Shemer for two talents of silver. He launched a construction project there and named the city he built after Shemer, the former owner of the hill of Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Omri did more evil in the sight of the Lord than all who were before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He followed in the footsteps of Jeroboam son of Nebat and encouraged Israel to sin; they angered the Lord God of Israel with their worthless idols.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events of Omri’s reign, including his accomplishments and successes, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Omri passed away and was buried in Samaria. His son Ahab replaced him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the thirty-eighth year of Asa’s reign over Judah, Omri’s son Ahab became king over Israel. Ahab son of Omri ruled over Israel for twenty-two years in Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab son of Omri did more evil in the sight of the Lord than all who were before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As if following in the sinful footsteps of Jeroboam son of Nebat were not bad enough, he married Jezebel the daughter of King Ethbaal of the Sidonians. Then he worshiped and bowed to Baal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He set up an altar for Baal in the temple of Baal he had built in Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab also made an Asherah pole; he did more to anger the Lord God of Israel than all the kings of Israel who were before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During Ahab’s reign, Hiel the Bethelite rebuilt Jericho. Abiram, his firstborn son, died when he laid the foundation; Segub, his youngest son, died when he erected its gates, in keeping with the Lord’s message that he had spoken through Joshua son of Nun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah the Tishbite, from Tishbe in Gilead, said to Ahab, “As certainly as the Lord God of Israel lives (whom I serve), there will be no dew or rain in the years ahead unless I give the command.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord’s message came to him:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Leave here and travel eastward. Hide out in the Kerith Valley near the Jordan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Drink from the stream; I have already told the ravens to bring you food there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he carried out the Lord’s message; he went and lived in the Kerith Valley near the Jordan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The ravens would bring him bread and meat each morning and evening, and he would drink from the stream.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After a while, the stream dried up because there had been no rain in the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord’s message came to him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Get up, go to Zarephath in Sidonian territory, and live there. I have already told a widow who lives there to provide for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he got up and went to Zarephath. When he went through the city gate, there was a widow gathering wood. He called out to her, “Please give me a little water in a cup, so I can take a drink.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As she went to get it, he called out to her, “Please bring me a piece of bread.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She said, “As certainly as the Lord your God lives, I have no food, except for a handful of flour in a jar and a little olive oil in a jug. Right now I am gathering a couple of sticks for a fire. Then I’m going home to make one final meal for my son and myself. After we have eaten that, we will die of starvation.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah said to her, “Don’t be afraid. Go and do as you planned. But first make me a small cake and bring it to me; then make something for yourself and your son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this is what the Lord God of Israel has said: ‘The jar of flour will not be empty and the jug of oil will not run out until the day the Lord makes it rain on the surface of the ground.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She went and did as Elijah told her; there was always enough food for Elijah and for her and her family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The jar of flour was never empty and the jug of oil never ran out, in keeping with the Lord’s message that he had spoken through Elijah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this the son of the woman who owned the house got sick. His illness was so severe he could no longer breathe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She asked Elijah, “Why, prophet, have you come to me to confront me with my sin and kill my son?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to her, “Hand me your son.” He took him from her arms, carried him to the upper room where he was staying, and laid him down on his bed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he called out to the Lord, “O Lord, my God, are you also bringing disaster on this widow I am staying with by killing her son?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He stretched out over the boy three times and called out to the Lord, “O Lord, my God, please let this boy’s breath return to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord answered Elijah’s prayer; the boy’s breath returned to him and he lived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah took the boy, brought him down from the upper room to the house, and handed him to his mother. Elijah then said, “See, your son is alive!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman said to Elijah, “Now I know that you are a prophet and that the Lord’s message really does come through you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some time later, in the third year of the famine, the Lord’s message came to Elijah, “Go, make an appearance before Ahab, so I may send rain on the surface of the ground.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Elijah went to make an appearance before Ahab.
Now the famine was severe in Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ahab summoned Obadiah, who supervised the palace. (Now Obadiah was a very loyal follower of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jezebel was killing the Lord’s prophets, Obadiah took 100 prophets and hid them in two caves in two groups of fifty. He also brought them food and water.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab told Obadiah, “Go through the land to all the springs and valleys. Maybe we can find some grazing areas so we can keep the horses and mules alive and not have to kill some of the animals.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They divided up the land between them to search it; Ahab went one way by himself and Obadiah went the other way by himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Obadiah was traveling along, Elijah met him. When he recognized him, he fell facedown to the ground and said, “Is it really you, my master, Elijah?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He replied, “Yes, go and say to your master, ‘Elijah is back.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Obadiah said, “What sin have I committed that you are ready to hand your servant over to Ahab for execution?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As certainly as the Lord your God lives, my master has sent to every nation and kingdom in an effort to find you. When they say, ‘He’s not here,’ he makes them swear an oath that they could not find you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now you say, ‘Go and say to your master, “Elijah is back.”’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when I leave you, the Lord’s Spirit will carry you away so I can’t find you. If I go tell Ahab I’ve seen you, he won’t be able to find you and he will kill me. That would not be fair, because your servant has been a loyal follower of the Lord from my youth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Certainly my master is aware of what I did when Jezebel was killing the Lord’s prophets. I hid 100 of the Lord’s prophets in two caves in two groups of fifty and I brought them food and water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now you say, ‘Go and say to your master, “Elijah is back,”’ but he will kill me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Elijah said, “As certainly as the Lord of Heaven’s Armies lives (whom I serve), I will make an appearance before him today.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Obadiah went and informed Ahab, the king went to meet Elijah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ahab saw Elijah, he said to him, “Is it really you, the one who brings disaster on Israel?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah replied, “I have not brought disaster on Israel. But you and your father’s dynasty have, by abandoning the Lord’s commandments and following the Baals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now send out messengers and assemble all Israel before me at Mount Carmel, as well as the 450 prophets of Baal and 400 prophets of Asherah whom Jezebel supports.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab sent messengers to all the Israelites and had the prophets assemble at Mount Carmel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah approached all the people and said, “How long are you going to be paralyzed by indecision? If the Lord is the true God, then follow him, but if Baal is, follow him!” But the people did not say a word.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah said to them: “I am the only prophet of the Lord who is left, but there are 450 prophets of Baal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let them bring us two bulls. Let them choose one of the bulls for themselves, cut it up into pieces, and place it on the wood. But they must not set it on fire. I will do the same to the other bull and place it on the wood. But I will not set it on fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then you will invoke the name of your god, and I will invoke the name of the Lord. The god who responds with fire will demonstrate that he is the true God.” All the people responded, “This will be a fair test.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah told the prophets of Baal, “Choose one of the bulls for yourselves and go first, for you are the majority. Invoke the name of your god, but do not light a fire.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they took a bull, as he had suggested, and prepared it. They invoked the name of Baal from morning until noon, saying, “Baal, answer us.” But there was no sound and no answer. They jumped around on the altar they had made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At noon Elijah mocked them, “Yell louder! After all, he is a god; he may be deep in thought, or perhaps he stepped out for a moment or has taken a trip. Perhaps he is sleeping and needs to be awakened.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they yelled louder and, in accordance with their prescribed ritual, mutilated themselves with swords and spears until their bodies were covered with blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Throughout the afternoon they were in an ecstatic frenzy, but there was no sound, no answer, and no response.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah then told all the people, “Approach me.” So all the people approached him. He repaired the altar of the Lord that had been torn down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Elijah took twelve stones, corresponding to the number of tribes that descended from Jacob, to whom the Lord’s message had come, “Israel will be your name.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With the stones he constructed an altar for the Lord. Around the altar he made a trench large enough to contain two seahs of seed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He arranged the wood, cut up the bull, and placed it on the wood. Then he said, “Fill four water jars and pour the water on the offering and the wood.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had done so, he said, “Do it again.” So they did it again. Then he said, “Do it a third time.” So they did it a third time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The water flowed down all sides of the altar and filled the trench.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When it was time for the evening offering, Elijah the prophet approached the altar and prayed: “O Lord God of Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, prove today that you are God in Israel and that I am your servant and have done all these things at your command.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Answer me, O Lord, answer me, so these people will know that you, O Lord, are the true God and that you are winning back their allegiance.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then fire from the Lord fell from the sky. It consumed the offering, the wood, the stones, and the dirt, and licked up the water in the trench.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the people saw this, they threw themselves down with their faces to the ground and said, “The Lord is the true God! The Lord is the true God!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah told them, “Seize the prophets of Baal! Don’t let even one of them escape!” So they seized them, and Elijah led them down to the Kishon Valley and executed them there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Elijah told Ahab, “Go on up and eat and drink, for the sound of a heavy rainstorm can be heard.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ahab went on up to eat and drink, while Elijah climbed to the top of Carmel. He bent down toward the ground and put his face between his knees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He told his servant, “Go on up and look in the direction of the sea.” So he went on up, looked, and reported, “There is nothing.” Seven times Elijah sent him to look.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The seventh time the servant said, “Look, a small cloud, the size of the palm of a man’s hand, is rising up from the sea.” Elijah then said, “Go and tell Ahab, ‘Hitch up the chariots and go down, so that the rain won’t overtake you.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile the sky was covered with dark clouds, the wind blew, and there was a heavy rainstorm. Ahab rode toward Jezreel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the Lord energized Elijah with power; he tucked his robe into his belt and ran ahead of Ahab all the way to Jezreel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab told Jezebel all that Elijah had done, including a detailed account of how he killed all the prophets with the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jezebel sent a messenger to Elijah with this warning, “May the gods judge me severely if by this time tomorrow I do not take your life as you did theirs!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah was afraid, so he got up and fled for his life to Beer Sheba in Judah. He left his servant there,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: while he went a day’s journey into the wilderness. He went and sat down under a shrub and asked the Lord to take his life: “I’ve had enough! Now, O Lord, take my life. After all, I’m no better than my ancestors.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He stretched out and fell asleep under the shrub. Suddenly an angelic messenger touched him and said, “Get up and eat.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He looked and right there by his head was a cake baking on hot coals and a jug of water. He ate and drank and then slept some more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The angel of the Lord came back again, touched him, and said, “Get up and eat, for otherwise you won’t be able to make the journey.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he got up and ate and drank. That meal gave him the strength to travel forty days and forty nights until he reached Horeb, the mountain of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He went into a cave there and spent the night. Suddenly the Lord’s message came to him, “Why are you here, Elijah?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He answered, “I have been absolutely loyal to the Lord God of Heaven’s Armies, even though the Israelites have abandoned the covenant they made with you, torn down your altars, and killed your prophets with the sword. I alone am left and now they want to take my life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord said, “Go out and stand on the mountain before the Lord. Look, the Lord is ready to pass by.”
A very powerful wind went before the Lord, digging into the mountain and causing landslides, but the Lord was not in the wind. After the windstorm there was an earthquake, but the Lord was not in the earthquake.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the earthquake, there was a fire, but the Lord was not in the fire. After the fire, there was a soft whisper.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Elijah heard it, he covered his face with his robe and went out and stood at the entrance to the cave. Suddenly a voice asked him, “Why are you here, Elijah?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He answered, “I have been absolutely loyal to the Lord God of Heaven’s Armies, even though the Israelites have abandoned the covenant they made with you, torn down your altars, and killed your prophets with the sword. I alone am left and now they want to take my life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to him, “Go back the way you came and then head for the wilderness of Damascus. Go and anoint Hazael king over Syria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must anoint Jehu son of Nimshi king over Israel, and Elisha son of Shaphat from Abel Meholah to take your place as prophet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehu will kill anyone who escapes Hazael’s sword, and Elisha will kill anyone who escapes Jehu’s sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I still have left in Israel 7,000 followers who have not bowed their knees to Baal or kissed the images of him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah went from there and found Elisha son of Shaphat. He was plowing with twelve pairs of oxen; he was near the twelfth pair. Elijah passed by him and threw his robe over him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He left the oxen, ran after Elijah, and said, “Please let me kiss my father and mother goodbye, then I will follow you.” Elijah said to him, “Go back! Indeed, what have I done to you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elisha went back and took his pair of oxen and slaughtered them. He cooked the meat over a fire that he made by burning the harness and yoke. He gave the people meat and they ate. Then he got up and followed Elijah and became his assistant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now King Ben Hadad of Syria assembled all his army, along with thirty-two other kings with their horses and chariots. He marched against Samaria and besieged and attacked it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sent messengers to King Ahab of Israel, who was in the city. He said to him, “This is what Ben Hadad says:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Your silver and your gold are mine, as well as the best of your wives and sons.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel replied, “It is just as you say, my master, O king. I and all I own belong to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The messengers came again and said, “This is what Ben Hadad says: ‘I sent this message to you, “You must give me your silver, gold, wives, and sons.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now at this time tomorrow I will send my servants to you and they will search through your palace and your servants’ houses. They will carry away all your valuables.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel summoned all the leaders of the land and said, “Notice how this man is looking for trouble. Indeed, he demanded my wives, sons, silver, and gold, and I did not resist him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the leaders and people said to him, “Do not give in or agree to his demands.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he said to the messengers of Ben Hadad, “Say this to my master, the king: ‘I will give you everything you demanded at first from your servant, but I am unable to agree to this latest demand.’” So the messengers went back and gave their report.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ben Hadad sent another message to him, “May the gods judge me severely if there is enough dirt left in Samaria for all my soldiers to scoop up in their hands.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel replied, “Tell him the one who puts on his battle gear should not boast like one who is taking it off.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ben Hadad received this reply, he and the other kings were drinking in their quarters. He ordered his servants, “Get ready to attack!” So they got ready to attack the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now a prophet visited King Ahab of Israel and said, “This is what the Lord has said: ‘Do you see this huge army? Look, I am going to hand it over to you this very day. Then you will know that I am the Lord.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab asked, “By whom will this be accomplished?” He answered, “This is what the Lord has said, ‘By the servants of the district governors.’” Ahab asked, “Who will launch the attack?” He answered, “You will.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ahab assembled the 232 servants of the district governors. After that he assembled all the Israelite army, numbering 7,000.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They marched out at noon, while Ben Hadad and the 32 kings allied with him were drinking heavily in their quarters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The servants of the district governors led the march. When Ben Hadad sent messengers, they reported back to him, “Men are marching out of Samaria.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He ordered, “Whether they come in peace or to do battle, take them alive.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They marched out of the city with the servants of the district governors in the lead and the army behind them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each one struck down an enemy soldier; the Syrians fled and Israel chased them. King Ben Hadad of Syria escaped on horseback with some horsemen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king of Israel marched out and struck down the horses and chariots; he thoroughly defeated Syria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The prophet visited the king of Israel and instructed him, “Go, fortify your defenses. Determine what you must do, for in the spring the king of Syria will attack you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the advisers of the king of Syria said to him: “Their God is a god of the mountains. That’s why they overpowered us. But if we fight them in the plains, we will certainly overpower them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So do this: Dismiss the kings from their command, and replace them with military commanders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Muster an army like the one you lost, with the same number of horses and chariots. Then we will fight them in the plains; we will certainly overpower them.” He approved their plan and did as they advised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the spring Ben Hadad mustered the Syrian army and marched to Aphek to fight Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Israelites had mustered and received their supplies, they marched out to face them in battle. When the Israelites deployed opposite them, they were like two small flocks of goats, but the Syrians filled the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The prophet visited the king of Israel and said, “This is what the Lord has said: ‘Because the Syrians said, “The Lord is a god of the mountains and not a god of the valleys,” I will deliver this entire huge army into to your control. Then you will know that I am the Lord.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The armies were deployed opposite each other for seven days. On the seventh day the battle began, and the Israelites killed 100,000 Syrian foot soldiers in one day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The remaining 27,000 ran to Aphek and went into the city, but the wall fell on them. Now Ben Hadad ran into the city and hid in an inner room.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His advisers said to him, “Look, we have heard that the kings of the Israelite dynasty are kind. Allow us to put sackcloth around our waists and ropes on our heads and surrender to the king of Israel. Maybe he will spare our lives.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they put sackcloth around their waists and ropes on their heads and went to the king of Israel. They said, “Your servant Ben Hadad says, ‘Please let me live!’” Ahab replied, “Is he still alive? He is my brother.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men took this as a good omen and quickly accepted his offer, saying, “Ben Hadad is your brother.” Ahab then said, “Go, get him.” So Ben Hadad came out to him, and Ahab pulled him up into his chariot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ben Hadad said, “I will return the cities my father took from your father. You may set up markets in Damascus, just as my father did in Samaria.” Ahab then said, “I want to make a treaty with you before I dismiss you.” So he made a treaty with him and then dismissed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One of the members of the prophetic guild told his companion a message from the Lord, “Please wound me!” But the man refused to wound him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the prophet said to him, “Because you have disobeyed the Lord, as soon as you leave me a lion will kill you.” When he left him, a lion attacked and killed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He found another man and said, “Wound me!” So the man wounded him severely.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The prophet then went and stood by the road, waiting for the king. He also disguised himself by putting a bandage down over his eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the king passed by, he called out to the king, “Your servant went out into the heat of the battle, and then a man turned aside and brought me a prisoner. He told me, ‘Guard this prisoner. If he ends up missing for any reason, you will pay with your life or with a talent of silver.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Well, it just so happened that while your servant was doing this and that, he disappeared.” The king of Israel said to him, “Your punishment is already determined by your own testimony.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The prophet quickly removed the bandage from his eyes, and the king of Israel recognized he was one of the prophets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The prophet then said to him, “This is what the Lord has said: ‘Because you released a man I had determined should die, you will pay with your life, and your people will suffer instead of his people.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel went home to Samaria bitter and angry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this the following episode took place. Naboth the Jezreelite owned a vineyard in Jezreel adjacent to the palace of King Ahab of Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab said to Naboth, “Give me your vineyard so I can make a vegetable garden out of it, for it is adjacent to my palace. I will give you an even better vineyard in its place, or if you prefer, I will pay you silver for it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Naboth replied to Ahab, “The Lord forbid that I should sell you my ancestral inheritance.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ahab went into his palace, bitter and angry that Naboth the Jezreelite had said, “I will not sell to you my ancestral inheritance.” He lay down on his bed, pouted, and would not eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then his wife Jezebel came in and said to him, “Why do you have a bitter attitude and refuse to eat?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He answered her, “While I was talking to Naboth the Jezreelite, I said to him, ‘Sell me your vineyard for silver, or if you prefer, I will give you another vineyard in its place.’ But he said, ‘I will not sell you my vineyard.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His wife Jezebel said to him, “You are the king of Israel! Get up, eat some food, and have a good time. I will get the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She wrote out orders, signed Ahab’s name to them, and sealed them with his seal. She then sent the orders to the leaders and to the nobles who lived in Naboth’s city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what she wrote: “Observe a time of fasting and seat Naboth in front of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also seat two villains opposite him and have them testify, ‘You cursed God and the king.’ Then take him out and stone him to death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of the city, the leaders, and the nobles who lived there followed the written orders Jezebel had sent them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They observed a time of fasting and put Naboth in front of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The two villains arrived and sat opposite him. Then the villains testified against Naboth right before the people, saying, “Naboth cursed God and the king.” So they dragged him outside the city and stoned him to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they reported to Jezebel, “Naboth has been stoned to death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jezebel heard that Naboth had been stoned to death, she said to Ahab, “Get up, take possession of the vineyard Naboth the Jezreelite refused to sell you for silver, for Naboth is no longer alive; he’s dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ahab heard that Naboth was dead, he got up and went down to take possession of the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord’s message came to Elijah the Tishbite:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Get up, go down and meet King Ahab of Israel who lives in Samaria. He is at the vineyard of Naboth; he has gone down there to take possession of it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Say to him, ‘This is what the Lord has said: “Haven’t you committed murder and taken possession of the property of the deceased?”’ Then say to him, ‘This is what the Lord has said: “In the spot where dogs licked up Naboth’s blood they will also lick up your blood—yes, yours!”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Elijah arrived, Ahab said to him, “So, you have found me, my enemy!” Elijah replied, “I have found you, because you are committed to doing evil in the sight of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord says, ‘Look, I am ready to bring disaster on you. I will destroy you and cut off every last male belonging to Ahab in Israel, including even the weak and incapacitated.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will make your dynasty like those of Jeroboam son of Nebat and Baasha son of Ahijah because you angered me and made Israel sin.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord says this about Jezebel, ‘Dogs will devour Jezebel by the outer wall of Jezreel.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for Ahab’s family, dogs will eat the ones who die in the city, and the birds of the sky will eat the ones who die in the country.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (There had never been anyone like Ahab, who was firmly committed to doing evil in the sight of the Lord, urged on by his wife Jezebel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was so wicked he worshiped the disgusting idols, just as the Amorites whom the Lord had driven out from before the Israelites.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ahab heard these words, he tore his clothes, put on sackcloth, and fasted. He slept in sackcloth and walked around dejected.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord’s message came to Elijah the Tishbite,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Have you noticed how Ahab shows remorse before me? Because he shows remorse before me, I will not bring disaster on his dynasty during his lifetime, but during the reign of his son.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was no war between Syria and Israel for three years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the third year King Jehoshaphat of Judah came down to visit the king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel said to his servants, “Surely you recognize that Ramoth Gilead belongs to us, though we are hesitant to reclaim it from the king of Syria.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said to Jehoshaphat, “Will you go with me to attack Ramoth Gilead?” Jehoshaphat replied to the king of Israel, “I will support you; my army and horses are at your disposal.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But then Jehoshaphat said to Israel’s king, “Please seek a message from the Lord this very day.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king of Israel assembled about 400 prophets and asked them, “Should I attack Ramoth Gilead or not?” They said, “Attack! The Sovereign One will hand it over to the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jehoshaphat asked, “Is there not a prophet of the Lord still here, that we may ask him?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel answered Jehoshaphat, “There is still one man through whom we can seek the Lord’s will. But I despise him because he does not prophesy prosperity for me, but disaster. His name is Micaiah son of Imlah.” Jehoshaphat said, “The king should not say such things.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel summoned an official and said, “Quickly bring Micaiah son of Imlah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the king of Israel and King Jehoshaphat of Judah were sitting on their respective thrones, dressed in their robes, at the threshing floor at the entrance of the gate of Samaria. All the prophets were prophesying before them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zedekiah son of Kenaanah made iron horns and said, “This is what the Lord has said, ‘With these you will gore Syria until they are destroyed.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the prophets were prophesying the same, saying, “Attack Ramoth Gilead! You will succeed; the Lord will hand it over to the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the messenger who went to summon Micaiah said to him, “Look, the prophets are in complete agreement that the king will succeed. Your words must agree with theirs; you must predict success.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Micaiah said, “As certainly as the Lord lives, I will say what the Lord tells me to say.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he came before the king, the king asked him, “Micaiah, should we attack Ramoth Gilead or not?” He answered him, “Attack! You will succeed; the Lord will hand it over to the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to him, “How many times must I make you solemnly promise in the name of the Lord to tell me only the truth?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Micaiah said, “I saw all Israel scattered on the mountains like sheep that have no shepherd. Then the Lord said, ‘They have no master. They should go home in peace.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, “Didn’t I tell you he does not prophesy prosperity for me, but disaster?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Micaiah said, “That being the case, listen to the Lord’s message. I saw the Lord sitting on his throne, with all the heavenly assembly standing beside him on his right and on his left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said, ‘Who will deceive Ahab, so he will attack Ramoth Gilead and die there?’ One said this and another that.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then a spirit stepped forward and stood before the Lord. He said, ‘I will deceive him.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord asked him, ‘How?’ He replied, ‘I will go out and be a lying spirit in the mouths of all his prophets.’ The Lord said, ‘Deceive and overpower him. Go out and do as you have proposed.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now, look, the Lord has placed a lying spirit in the mouths of all these prophets of yours, but the Lord has decreed disaster for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zedekiah son of Kenaanah approached, hit Micaiah on the jaw, and said, “Which way did the Lord’s Spirit go when he went from me to speak to you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Micaiah replied, “Look, you will see in the day when you go into an inner room to hide.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king of Israel said, “Take Micaiah and return him to Amon the city official and Joash the king’s son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Say, ‘This is what the king says, “Put this man in prison. Give him only a little bread and water until I safely return.”’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Micaiah said, “If you really do safely return, then the Lord has not spoken through me.” Then he added, “Take note, all you people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel and King Jehoshaphat of Judah attacked Ramoth Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, “I will disguise myself and then enter into the battle, but you wear your royal robes.” So the king of Israel disguised himself and then entered into the battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the king of Syria had ordered his thirty-two chariot commanders, “Do not fight common soldiers or high-ranking officers; fight only the king of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the chariot commanders saw Jehoshaphat, they said, “He must be the king of Israel.” So they turned and attacked him, but Jehoshaphat cried out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the chariot commanders realized he was not the king of Israel, they turned away from him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now an archer shot an arrow at random, and it struck the king of Israel between the plates of his armor. The king ordered his charioteer, “Turn around and take me from the battle line, because I’m wounded.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While the battle raged throughout the day, the king stood propped up in his chariot opposite the Syrians. He died in the evening; the blood from the wound ran down into the bottom of the chariot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the sun was setting, a cry went through the camp, “Each one should return to his city and to his homeland.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king died and was taken to Samaria, where they buried him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They washed off the chariot at the pool of Samaria. Then the dogs licked his blood, while the prostitutes bathed, in keeping with the Lord’s message that he had spoken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events of Ahab’s reign, including a record of his accomplishments and how he built a luxurious palace and various cities, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab passed away. His son Ahaziah replaced him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the fourth year of Ahab’s reign over Israel, Asa’s son Jehoshaphat became king over Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat was thirty-five years old when he became king and he reigned for twenty-five years in Jerusalem. His mother was Azubah, the daughter of Shilhi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He followed in his father Asa’s footsteps and was careful to do what the Lord approved. (22:44) However, the high places were not eliminated; the people continued to offer sacrifices and burn incense on the high places.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (22:45) Jehoshaphat was also at peace with the king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rest of the events of Jehoshaphat’s reign, including his successes and military exploits, are recorded in the scroll called the Annals of the Kings of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He removed from the land any male cultic prostitutes who had managed to survive the reign of his father Asa.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was no king in Edom at this time; a governor ruled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat built a fleet of large merchant ships to travel to Ophir for gold, but they never made the voyage because they were shipwrecked in Ezion Geber.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ahaziah son of Ahab said to Jehoshaphat, “Let my sailors join yours in the fleet,” but Jehoshaphat refused.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat passed away and was buried with his ancestors in the city of his ancestor David. His son Jehoram replaced him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the seventeenth year of Jehoshaphat’s reign over Judah, Ahab’s son Ahaziah became king over Israel in Samaria. He ruled for two years over Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did evil in the sight of the Lord and followed in the footsteps of his father and mother; like Jeroboam son of Nebat, he encouraged Israel to sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He worshiped and bowed down to Baal, angering the Lord God of Israel just as his father had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator
